Yet millions of Indian professionals still follow it blindly, sacrificing their most valuable years for a security that no longer exists. The Hidden Cost of "Stability": ğŸ‘‰Your skills depreciate while company equity appreciates ğŸ‘‰Single income source = maximum vulnerability in uncertain times ğŸ‘‰Trading peak energy years (20s-30s) for minimal growth ğŸ‘‰Building someone else's vision while your potential stays dormant ğŸ‘‰No ownership, no leverage, no exit strategy The New Career Math for India 2025: Employment â‰  Security anymore. The real security comes from: â†’ Skill stacking (technical + business + communication) â†’ Multiple income channels (consulting, products, investments) â†’ Personal brand equity (network + reputation + visibility) â†’ Ownership mindset (equity over salary) This isn't anti-job. This is pro-strategy. Use employment as a launchpad, not a destination. Learn on company time, build on your time, transition when you're ready. The uncomfortable truth: Your company has a succession plan for your role. Do you have a succession plan for your income? For real career frameworks that work in Indian context: Follow Nidhisha Rao. Ph.D â€” No motivational fluff. Just systems, strategies, and stories from people building real freedom. #CareerStrategy #IndianProfessionals #CareerGrowth #SkillDevelopment #FinancialFreedom #CareerTransition #FutureOfWork #PersonalBrand #IncomeStreams #ProfessionalGrowth #CareerAdvice #IndiaJobs #Entrepreneurship #CareerPlanning #WorkLifeBalance

Cultural Shift Age defines career opportunities in India. If you are 50+ years of age and a part of lower or middle management, you are projected as an experienced person, of whom, everyone wants to Utilize Expertise and nomenclature them as â€œGuiding Forceâ€. In Hindi, we call them â€œMarg Darshak Mandalâ€. They are good to consult, but not good for positional growth and that is ironic. Recently, I was interacting with one of the colleagues in Industry and he mentioned that in their organization, they have put a block to recruit and select person of a particular age, even for a senior position. Presumption is that young blood brings energy and zest, and ageing is letting zest and energy evaporate. When a narrative like this, though may not be a truth, when spoken with conviction, repeatedly, it becomes a truth, and everyone starts believing it. Paradigms are changing. People are becoming increasingly self-aware of their physical and mental health from an early age. Differentiating between the biological age vs chronological age, there is an inverse relationship in many cases, yet taboo or confirmational bias of age vs productivity makes relationship between chronological age vs biological age, a directly proportional equation. In fact, Age is just a number. Of late, I have seen some forward thinkers who, on contrary are inviting retired professionals as consultants to make their businesses successful. Professional qualifications do add value to oneâ€™s career and can give a jump start, however, they learn from experiences of experienced people who may or may not have a fancy degree but the real-world experience, where rubber meets the ground. While imbibing nectar of real world experiences and temporarily getting nurtured and getting their own feet, many of the times, many of them tumble with tumultuous sound because they are still far away from reality and with limited learning, they are just able to manage their field related challenges. Their fancy degrees keep them on a growth trajectory. Future may be an extension of past or may not be, the one who is ready to adapt to ever changing environment, irrespective of chronological age, is going to excel. The person may not grow positionally but will have an acumen of a person of Senior Leadership position. Ergo, in name of leveraging the strengths of individuals, invest further on individuals who are willing to take higher responsibilities, irrespective of age. This will not only optimize business outcomes but will set a culture that inspires and makes Organizations from â€œGood to Greatâ€.

â€œFollow your passionâ€ is the worst career advice given to Indian students. And every graduation speech repeats it like a ritual. Hereâ€™s the uncomfortable truth: For 90% of Indians, passion doesnâ€™t pay rent. That advice only works when: â€¢ your family can financially back you for YEARS â€¢ failure doesnâ€™t have big consequences â€¢ the ecosystem rewards experimentation Thatâ€™s not reality for most Indian households. So what should you do instead? Donâ€™t follow your passion. Build your leverage. Hereâ€™s a better framework: Step 1: Pick a skill the market already pays for: Finance. Tech. Sales. Analytics. Law. Not because you â€œloveâ€ it, but because it buys you stability. Step 2: Get dangerously good at it This gives you income, credibility and optionality. Step 3: Use stability to explore passion Once survival is handled, curiosity becomes fun. Thatâ€™s when you get into your passion. Most successful people didnâ€™t start with passion. They started with practical competence. Passion came later. After skills. After income. After leverage. Dreams are important. But starving for them is optional. The real privilege isnâ€™t â€œdoing what you loveâ€. Itâ€™s having the freedom to choose if you want to do anything at all. #Passion #Purpose #Work

ğŸš¨ Mid-Life Career Reality Check (India) ğŸš¨ Back in 2025, a strong buzz started in corporate circles: ğŸ‘‰ Employees in their mid-40s are increasingly vulnerable to job loss. Today, this is no longer just buzz. Major Indian dailies and business newspapers have now confirmed this trend. This is not fear-mongering â€” itâ€™s a wake-up call. ğŸ” Major reasons behind the mid-life career crisis: 1ï¸âƒ£ AI & Automation are no longer â€œfuture risksâ€ AI today is faster, scalable, and in many tech, IT, and media roles, more efficient than we ever imagined. Roles that once required experience now require continuous reinvention. 2ï¸âƒ£ Comfort zone culture In India, once many professionals get a stable job, they unconsciously enter a comfort zone. âŒ Skills stop evolving âŒ Learning slows down âŒ Relevance declines The market, however, never stops evolving. 3ï¸âƒ£ Cost pressure on companies Organizations want to reduce: High fixed salaries Long-term obligations (ESI, PF, gratuity, compliances) Experienced employees often become financially heavy for cost-cutting companies. 4ï¸âƒ£ Salary vs value mismatch Experience alone is no longer enough. If cost > current value, businesses make tough calls. 5ï¸âƒ£ Indiaâ€™s population reality Letâ€™s be honest: ğŸ‘‰ Ek anar, sau bimaar. There is no shortage of younger, cheaper, and hungry talent waiting to replace you. âš ï¸ Special caution for mid-life professionals who: Have young children Carry heavy EMI burdens Have a family history of health issues Depend on single income For them, job loss is not just a career issue â€” itâ€™s a life crisis. âœ… My advice to professionals approaching or in mid-life: âœ”ï¸ Continuously upgrade your skill set âœ”ï¸ Donâ€™t rely on a single income â€” build side income âœ”ï¸ Turn your hobby into a profession âœ”ï¸ Explore part-time, consulting, or freelancing work âœ”ï¸ Ideally, ensure both spouses are financially active âœ”ï¸ Prepare before the crisis arrives â€” not after ğŸ“Œ Mid-life should be your most powerful phase, not your weakest â€” if you prepare for it. Wrong degree, no interest in IT, or gap years â€” most people feel stuck not because they lack ability, but because they donâ€™t understand how careers actually work in India. I went through this phase myself and realized motivation doesnâ€™t solve confusion â€” clarity does. So I put together a small, practical guide based on real Indian job market thinking. No hype. No promises. Just clear perspective. If this helps even one person think clearly, itâ€™s worth it. Link in comments. #CareerClarity #CareerConfusion #IndianJobMarket

In India, being unemployed is more respectable than working at McDonaldâ€™s. How crazy is that? A large number of Indian students between 18 and 26 would genuinely prefer staying at home, scrolling Instagram, and waiting for the â€œright opportunityâ€ rather than taking up a job at a cafÃ©/retail store, or fast-food chain. Not because the work is difficult, exhausting, or beneath their capability, but because it is socially labelled as embarrassing. Whatâ€™s interesting is that the exact same jobs carry very different meanings elsewhere. In the US, working part-time in retail or fast food is considered a normal part of growing up. In the UK, itâ€™s seen as a respectable hustle. In Japan, itâ€™s understood as a way to build discipline, responsibility, and character. In India, however, the first reaction is often: â€œWhat will people say?â€ Somewhere along the way, weâ€™ve created a value system where earning â‚¹15,000 a month through honest work is looked down upon, while sitting at home with no income, no experience, and no exposure is quietly accepted. And that should worry us. Early work experience teaches almost everything employers actually care about - showing up on time, dealing with people, managing pressure, taking responsibility, and understanding how money and systems work in the real world. These are skills no degree or online certification can replace. Yet many students remain stuck in a status quo mindset: â€œI have a degree. I shouldnâ€™t be doing retail or service jobs.â€ Meanwhile, students abroad are building real-world competence, confidence, and independence, while we are perfecting resumes filled with qualifications but no practical experience. This is the real difference: A status mindset waits for the perfect role, the perfect title, and the perfect start. A skill mindset starts anywhere, learns fast, and builds forward. No job is too small. No honest work is embarrassing. The real risk is not being judged by others; itâ€™s losing valuable years waiting for approval instead of building capability. So the question isnâ€™t whether a job matches your â€œstatus.â€ The question is whether your mindset is preparing you for the real world.

Why *Abroad* Feels Like the Safer Dream for Gen Z (An Honest Take) In India, the career ladder is often introduced early and very clearly... First IIT-JEE. Then NEET. Then government exams. If you step off this ladder... not because youâ€™re incapable, but because youâ€™re questioning it..confusion begins. For many in Gen Z, choosing government service isnâ€™t just about stability or power anymore. It comes with a quieter, heavier question- *Do I want to be part of a system that often asks conformity before conscience?* This is rarely spoken about. When you observe governance closely, you realise that being *in the system* is complex. It isnâ€™t only about salary, authority, or social respect. Itâ€™s about navigating structures where good intent can feel misplaced, slow, or misaligned with ground realities. And when someone has a decent intellect, curiosity, and ethical discomfort, the conflict deepens. At that point, *abroad* doesnâ€™t just represent money or lifestyle. It represents merit being clearer, roles being defined, effort feeling less diluted. It feels like a space where one can work with the system rather than constantly negotiate against it. This is not escape. Itâ€™s a search for alignment. Gen Z is not detached from responsibility or nation-building. But many are weary of systems that discourage questioning and reward silence. Maybe the real issue isnâ€™t brain drain. Maybe itâ€™s that we havenâ€™t made enough room for thinking, integrity, and psychological agency within our own systems. Until we do, people wonâ€™t just look outward for opportunity..theyâ€™ll look for environments where their intelligence can breathe.ğŸ“Œ #youth #genz #psychology

For decades, many Indian graduates were advised to follow a single, low-risk career strategy: secure a role with a large IT services firm, remain loyal, and expect long-term stability and progression. That model is steadily losing relevance. In an AI-driven, productivity-focused economy, scale no longer guarantees individual security. Being one professional among hundreds of thousands can diluteâ€”not protectâ€”personal leverage. Several structural patterns are becoming evident across large IT organizations: Excess bench capacity reduces bargaining power, as talent abundance weakens individual differentiation. Extended tenure in legacy support and maintenance roles offers income stability but limits skill portability and long-term market value. Compensation risk increasingly appears through indirect mechanismsâ€”variable pay adjustments, delayed hikes, and cost rationalizationâ€”resulting in gradual earnings erosion without formal layoffs. This is not a critique of corporate intent. Organizations are responding rationally to margin pressure, automation, and changing client economics. However, it is a critical signal for early-career and mid-career professionals. Brand loyalty alone is no longer a sufficient career strategy. When learning velocity slows and earning potential plateaus, organizational affiliation cannot offset declining individual competitiveness. Looking toward 2026 and beyond, job security is less about where you work and more about what you can deliver. Sustainable careers will be built on continuously relevant skills, adaptability to emerging technologies, and the willingness to change roles or environments when the return on time and effort no longer compounds. Employability, not tenure, is the new measure of security.

Over the last seven months on campus, Iâ€™ve interacted with people from every possible mindsetâ€”ambitious builders, cautious planners, confused wanderers, and those who simply want to play it safe. These conversations have taught me something uncomfortable but important about the aspirations of our generation. A strange pattern keeps repeating itself. Whenever I nudge friends to pick up skillsâ€”AI, communication, internships, real-world exposureâ€”the response often comes wrapped in one line: â€œChhod naâ€¦ mujhe toh sarkari job hi karni hai.â€ Not because they are passionate about public service, not because they want to contribute to governanceâ€”but because it promises security, predictability, and a fixed salary. This isnâ€™t ambition. This is fear wearing the mask of practicality. Thereâ€™s nothing wrong with wanting stability. The problem starts when stability becomes the ceiling of aspiration. A mindset that chooses minimum risk automatically accepts minimum growth. And when millions think this way, the country doesnâ€™t move forwardâ€”it stagnates. Our government departments struggle not because India lacks talent, but because most people entering them are not driven by innovation or purpose. They are driven by the desire to avoid discomfort. When the primary goal of a job becomes â€œnot getting fired,â€ creativity dies. When people prioritise power over performance, systems decay. When the chase is for secure income instead of real impact, the ecosystem becomes vulnerable to inefficiency and corruption. Corruption is rarely born from evil intentions. It comes from small, convenient compromises, the mindset of â€œthoda adjust kar lo,â€ or â€œyeh hi system hai.â€ When individuals enter public roles only for money, perks, and security, they naturally slide into shortcuts and bargains that look harmless at first but eventually rot institutions from the inside. On the other hand, the students who push themselvesâ€”learn AI, build projects, network, experiment, fail, restartâ€”these are the people who strengthen Indiaâ€™s innovation engine. They expand possibilities instead of shrinking them. They look beyond the comfort of a monthly salary and actually create value. Our country doesnâ€™t need a youth running toward safety. It needs a youth running toward capability. Toward skills. Toward responsibility. Toward building something that lasts. If the next generation chooses convenience over competence, India will lose decades of progress. But if even a fraction chooses to push themselves, the compounding impact will be massive. The truth is simple: You can chase comfort, or you can chase growth. One gives you certainty. The other gives you a future. And the future is where this country needs us. #GrowthMindset #CareerAdvice #India #FutureOfWork #Upskilling #skill #ArtificialIntelligence #SSC #Real

It always feels inspiring to see your posts, especially with such well-crafted and meaningful clips. This truly reflects the way we worked in earlier daysâ€”growing step by step through life with a strong growth mindset. Those who think differently take bold steps to come out of the rat race and create their own path. Earlier, the journey of growth was challenging and often driven by perseverance rather than visibility. However, times have changed, and today we have the opportunity to accelerate growth by embracing a true growth mindset.

Suniel Bhai! your post captures the essence of Indian careers perfectlyâ€”that early pivot from passion to practicality builds unmatched range. I felt it firsthand: As an Air NCC cadet at BHU Varanasi, I earned my PPL through the flying club and cleared PABT for the Indian Air Force. But as the only son, parental concerns steered me elsewhere post my PG from JNU. Corporate stability followed, evolving into farming, land management, and community leadership today. Those â€œnecessaryâ€ choices honed adaptability that serves me still. In a dynamic world, usefulness trumps perfection. Spot on!

This hits home for a lot of people especially in India. Most careers here donâ€™t begin with choice, they begin with responsibility. And thatâ€™s not a weakness; itâ€™s a quiet strength. What youâ€™ve articulated beautifully is something we rarely acknowledge enough: Early work isnâ€™t about identity, itâ€™s about utility Stability comes before self-actualisation Adaptability is learned not in classrooms, but under pressure That â€œdoing what makes senseâ€ phase builds something far more valuable than passion ever could at that stage range, humility, and work ethic. Skills compound quietly when youâ€™re busy being useful. Your point about never seeing yourself as â€œthe filmstarâ€ but as a professional among professionals is especially powerful. That mindset travels across industries. It earns trust. And trust, more than talent, creates longevity. Indian careers zigzag not because people are confused but because circumstances train them to survive first and specialise later. In a volatile world, that ability to stay steady, learn fast, and adjust without drama is an unfair advantage. Usefulness before perfection. Stability before clarity. Depth after momentum. Thatâ€™s not compromise thatâ€™s wisdom earned the hard way.
Well said. Completely agree with you.

Beautifully put. Resilience isn't just about 'standing still' under pressure; it's about the 'quick adjustments' and adaptability you highlighted. Clarity does indeed come after stability. For anyone scaling a business or a career, being 'useful' in the moment often creates more value than following a perfect roadmap. Great perspective.

This hits hard because itâ€™s real for so many of us. Most careers donâ€™t begin with clarity, they begin with responsibility. What looks like â€œsettlingâ€ early on often becomes the foundation for adaptability, range, and resilience later. Pressure teaches skills passion alone never could. Loved the reminder that usefulness before perfection is what actually moves careers forward.

post_text_html:
Many Indian careers donâ€™t start with passion. A lot of them start with pressure.

Pressure of finding that first job. In search of that hope that things are finally starting to fall into place.

For so many people starting out, the early years are less about pursuing what we love and more about doing what makes sense.

What feels feasible. What keeps things moving.

There isnâ€™t much room to be picky when expectations are riding on you.

Parents who stretched themselves to educate you. Bills to pay. The simple understanding that things must work out.

So choices become practical. Opportunities are taken up not because they are perfect, but because they are available or make sense.

For many, the focus is less on passion and more on stability and momentum. At the time, it doesnâ€™t feel strategic. It just feels necessary.

But over the years, something interesting happens.

That phase of figuring things out builds range. You start picking up skills you never planned for.

Working across functions. Solving problems outside your actual role. Understanding how different parts of the system work.

My early years were a lot like that in fact.

I started out assuming my future was going to be in Dadâ€™s restaurant business. So I studied hotel management to prepare.

Those early years in the restaurant were totally different from what I expected. You do everything. There are no titles. No job is too small.

That experience built an entrepreneurial drive in me which led me to retail and fashion.

And when films eventually happened, the work ethic stayed.

On a film set, I was never the filmstar. I was another professional doing his part, like every other technician.

And that reputation has served me better than most of my successful films have.

Indian professionals develop this adaptability early. Not because they planned for it. But because circumstances demanded it.

Clarity usually comes later. Once there is stability. Once the pressure eases just a little.

Thatâ€™s when people begin choosing areas they want to go deeper in, and where they can truly excel.

And when change shows up, a new role, a new industry, an unexpected turn, that adaptability becomes the advantage.

There is no panic. No freezing. Just some quick adjustments.

Maybe thatâ€™s why so many Indian careers donâ€™t follow straight lines and still work out well.

Not because everything was mapped out. But because usefulness came before perfection.

In a world that keeps shifting, the ability to stay relevant, stay curious and stay steady really matters more than it looks on paper.

title: apidays Newsletter #2 - API Maturity: Why the Work Has Shifted from Building More to Managing Better
headline: Big Story: API Maturity Shifts Focus From Expansion to Management Key Takeaways API work at scale is increasingly focused on stabilizing and clarifying existing behavior. As usage grows, undocumented behavior and edge cases become primary sources of operational risk and support burden.
post_text: Big Story: API Maturity Shifts Focus From Expansion to Management Key Takeaways API work at scale is increasingly focused on stabilizing and clarifying existing behavior. As usage grows, undocumented behavior and edge cases become primary sources of operational risk and support burden. Release cycles are shifting toward limits, observability, configuration, and policy controls that make real-world API usage more predictable. In many organizations, API development has shifted away from rapid surface expansion toward ongoing operational refinement. New endpoints continue to be introduced, but they represent a smaller share of overall effort. Most API work now centers on clarifying contracts, tightening edge cases, and reducing the operational cost of how APIs are already used in production. This trend is visible in recent platform and gateway release notes. Updates increasingly emphasize limits, quotas, metadata, observability, configuration, and policy controls. Teams are adjusting defaults, formalizing behaviors that were previously implicit, and adding instrumentation to better understand established traffic patterns. Once an API reaches broad adoption, change becomes expensive. Consumers may rely on undocumented behavior. Automated clients encode timing assumptions. Minor inconsistencies can trigger retries, retries amplify load, and load exposes weaknesses that were irrelevant at lower volumes. As usage stabilizes, API teams focus on making behavior explicit and predictable. Error responses are standardized. Pagination and filtering rules are formalized. Rate limits are tuned based on observed usage rather than theoretical capacity. Timeouts and retries are documented and enforced more consistently. While these efforts are not highly visible, they reduce incident frequency, support overhead, and operational variance. This shift also changes how API success is evaluated. Instead of measuring progress by the number of new endpoints or integrations, teams track stability indicators like fewer incidents tied to ambiguous behavior, lower variability in request patterns, and more predictable cost profiles. For mature API programs, this pattern is becoming normal. The primary challenge is deciding which existing behaviors should be preserved, constrained, or removed. Over time, the value of the API is defined by how consistently it behaves. API Feed OpenAI disclosed that its API business added over $1 billion in annual recurring revenue in a single month, according to comments from Sam Altman, signaling that OpenAIÊ¼s core growth engine is shifting from consumer subscriptions toward infrastructure and developer-led usage. ( Reference ) PostmanÊ¼s v11 release continues shifting the platform from a request-centric API client toward an agent-ready API workbench, with Agent Mode and MCP server capabilities integrated alongside core lifecycle tools such as Specs, Flows, Governance, and Workspaces. ( Reference ) Google Cloud API Gateway added support for publishing API metadata to Apigee API hub, enabling a centralized inventory of APIs across gateways for discovery and governance. This addresses API sprawl directly by making the complete surface area visible and standardized, which is a prerequisite for controlling machine-driven usage and assigning clear ownership at scale. ( Reference ) CeligoÊ¼s January 2026 release focuses on operational upgrades for integration-heavy environments, including improved navigation, API usage, and entitlement visibility at the subscription level, higher per-connection concurrency limits, deeper connection diagnostics, and real-time SQL Server CDC exports to reduce polling overhead. These changes reflect a broader shift in integration platforms toward acting as governance and observability layers for API consumption, as the operational cost of opaque, high-volume automation continues to rise. ( Reference ) Community Spotlight Erik Wilde: Making API Contracts Machine-Readable at Scale As APIs shift from being human-operated integration points to machine-consumed execution surfaces, the teams that succeed are the ones that invest in clarity and coordination. ThatÊ¼s why Erik Wilde has become an increasingly important voice for API and platform leaders navigating this transition. An OpenAPI Initiative ambassador and long-time API researcher, Wilde focuses on how standards, contracts, and governance actually work in large, multi-team environments. Rather than treating OpenAPI as documentation, Wilde frames it as a coordination mechanism. His work emphasizes that most large API programs fail because interfaces drift, ownership becomes unclear, and contracts stop reflecting reality. In an agentic world, those gaps are actively dangerous because automated clients guess, retry, and amplify ambiguity instead of asking clarifying questions. In recent writing and talks, Wilde has pushed on a question many enterprises are only starting to confront: whether their API descriptions are truly usable by machines. That means schemas that are complete, error semantics that are explicit, and versioning policies that reflect how systems actually evolve. As agents begin chaining APIs autonomously, these details determine whether workflows remain predictable or quietly degrade under load. WildeÊ¼s perspective is especially valuable because it avoids hype. He doesnÊ¼t argue that standards will magically solve agentic complexity. Instead, he shows how disciplined API description and governance reduce risk, improve reuse, and make automated consumption safer by default. For platform teams, the takeaway is that API contracts are becoming part of the enterprise operating system, and treating them casually is no longer an option. The program blends practical case studies and technical sessions across API management, security, governance, and automation. ItÊ¼s built for senior practitioners and decision-makers, bringing together 1,500+ participants from 1,000+ companies, making it a strong anchor event for anyone tracking where enterprise API strategy is heading next. Details â†’ ğŸ“… PlatformCon Live (New York, NY - June 25, 2026) PlatformCon Live brings together platform and API practitioners working on internal platforms at scale, with sessions centered on API ownership, platform operating models, and the day-to-day realities of supporting large developer ecosystems. Details â†’ ğŸ“… Google Cloud Next 2026 (Las Vegas, NV - April 22-24, 2026) Google Cloud Next is a strong U.S. anchor event for platform and API leaders because itÊ¼s where enterprise teams compare notes on building governed AI systems in production. Expect heavy coverage of API management, identity and policy controls, observability, and the practical infrastructure patterns teams use when machine-driven workloads start dominating traffic. It outlines how traffic visibility, behavioral analysis, and usage attribution are being used to improve security and reliability. Read â†’ Insight of the Week API security is shifting from perimeter defense to runtime enforcement, as enterprises accept that APIs are now the primary attack surface for automated and agent-driven systems. RadwareÊ¼s launch of an end-to-end API Security Service reflects this move toward inspecting live production traffic, detecting behavioral abuse, and protecting business logic rather than relying only on gateways, schemas, or static rules. title: Fact is, a majority of us Indians, whether entrepreneurs, founders or professionals, think very differently about risk compared to how it is discussed or celebrated. Itâ€™s not that we are afraid ofâ€¦ | Suniel Shetty | 528 comments
headline: Fact is, a majority of us Indians, whether entrepreneurs, founders or professionals, think very differently about risk compared to how it is discussed or celebrated.
post_text: Fact is, a majority of us Indians, whether entrepreneurs, founders or professionals, think very differently about risk compared to how it is discussed or celebrated. Itâ€™s not that we are afraid of it. We just donâ€™t romanticise it. On social media, risk often sounds glamorous. Go all in. Take the leap. Do it now or stay stuck. But on the ground, we know life looks very different. For many of us, there is a lot riding on our choices. Parents back home whoâ€™ve put their lifeâ€™s savings into education. Families that depend on a monthly income. Loans. EMIs. Responsibilities that donâ€™t pause while you figure things out. When you come from a simple background, risk is not theoretical. Itâ€™s personal. So decisions tend to be measured. Thought through. Taken with a clear understanding of what can be stretched, and what cannot be lost. Iâ€™ve seen people work incredibly hard, take smart chances, and still choose not to take big risks with their careers. Not because they lack ambition. But because failure doesnâ€™t affect only them. This applies just as much to a professional deciding whether to quit a stable and safe job, as it does to a founder deciding how fast to scale. All or nothing sounds exciting in interviews of people who made it. In real life, it can cost far more than it appears. Your appetite for risk is tied to your circumstances. What I respect about this mindset is the strength it builds. When you build with responsibility, you are forced to think long term. You pace yourself. You learn to survive slow months, bad phases and unexpected turns. That doesnâ€™t make you cautious. It makes you prepared. I relate to this personally. In my early years in films, I played it safe with the kind of roles I chose. Action films mainly. Familiar territory. I needed to secure my place, stay relevant and keep getting work. Only later, when it was safer did I start taking risks with different roles and genres. Films that were a little hatke for their time. Hu Tu Tu with Gulzar saab. Comedies like Hera Pheri. I was convinced these risks would pay off, but the fact was I just couldnâ€™t afford to take them earlier. If youâ€™re in a phase where you canâ€™t take big leaps, it doesnâ€™t mean your options are limited. It just means your path will unfold differently. Everyoneâ€™s journey is unique. There is no single correct timeline. The goal is not to win fast. Itâ€™s to stay in the game long enough to win well. Risk, when taken with awareness, doesnâ€™t shrink your dreams. It gives them the space to grow, at the right time.

But as you pointed out through films like Hu Tu Tu with Gulzar or comedies like Hera Pheri, the freedom to experiment often comes after stability, not before it. That sequencing matters. title: apidays Newsletter #4 - Debugging in an AI-Generated Integration World
headline: Big Story: Debugging in an AI-Generated Integration World Key Takeaways AI-assisted coding increases API integration speed while reducing visibility into underlying assumptions. Debugging moves from reading the code to understanding how API interactions actually behave across systems.
post_text: Big Story: Debugging in an AI-Generated Integration World Key Takeaways AI-assisted coding increases API integration speed while reducing visibility into underlying assumptions. Debugging moves from reading the code to understanding how API interactions actually behave across systems. Observability, contract clarity, and ownership become primary safeguards in automated API environments. AI-assisted development has changed how API integrations are created. Code that once required careful reading of API documentation, deliberate implementation, and peer review can now be generated in seconds. When a developer writes integration logic manually, they internalize the API contracts they are working with. They understand why a retry exists, why a transformation is needed to match a schema, or why a fallback call to another endpoint was added. When integration code is generated by an AI system, those decisions are often implicit. The code may successfully call the API and return valid responses, but the assumptions about rate limits, idempotency, pagination, or error semantics are rarely examined in depth. This changes debugging. Failures no longer present as simple implementation errors. They appear as behavioral mismatches across services connected through APIs. The challenge is that the design rationale behind how the API was consumed is undocumented. In traditional workflows, debugging begins by reviewing recent code changes and matching them against API documentation. In an AI-assisted workflow, prompts evolve, context windows shift, and regeneration alters structure without explicit explanation. Observability at the API layer becomes foundational. Structured logs, distributed traces, and explicit correlation identifiers are necessary to reconstruct execution paths across internal and external APIs. Telemetry must capture not only request and response metadata but also contextual signals such as retries, conditional branches, token usage, and downstream dependency calls. Ownership clarity becomes equally important. As AI tools generate more API integrations, it must be clear which team owns each API dependency and its lifecycle. Another emerging consideration is reproducibility. When integration logic that consumes APIs is generated through prompts, reproducing the exact conditions under which it was created can be difficult. Teams are beginning to store prompt artifacts alongside integration code, treating them as part of the implementation record. Testing strategies also evolve. Behavioral drift across chained API calls requires scenario-based testing and contract validation. In an environment where machines generate integration code, debugging becomes an exercise in reconstructing API intent from observable behavior. Systems must be instrumented in ways that make that reconstruction feasible. API Feed CX Today reported that a misconfigured backend in the AI-agent social network Moltbook exposed sensitive data, including API authentication tokens, private messages, and user email addresses, enabling unauthorized access to the production database. The incident illustrates how fast-built, API-driven products can ship without secure defaults, and why token handling, row-level access controls, and configuration review need to be treated as part of the API security measures. ( Reference ) Lone Wolf Technologies launched a centralized API Portal to provide brokers, agents, and partners with secure access to Lone Wolf APIs for connecting systems, automating workflows, and using real-time data across its cloud ecosystem. ( Reference ) Google added a developer preview path to build Google Chat apps as Google Workspace add-ons that use Cloud PubSub to receive messages. This enables event-driven architectures for Chat integrations that can run behind firewalls, and it pushes teams toward more standardized message ingestion and operational controls for internal automation. ( Reference ) Community Spotlight Kin Lane: Treating APIs as Organizational Memory Kin Lane has spent more than a decade mapping the API landscape as an independent analyst documenting how APIs are actually designed, governed, and maintained. Through his long-running work at API Evangelist, Lane has catalogued patterns across industries, highlighting where APIs succeed, where they decay, and where governance quietly breaks down. He focuses on the lifecycle of APIs inside organizations, from early experimentation to version sprawl and documentation drift. His work repeatedly shows that most API problems are not technical edge cases but organizational ones. As automation and AI-driven systems increase the number of integrations inside enterprises, LaneÊ¼s framing becomes more relevant. More endpoints mean more surface area. More surface area means more potential for inconsistency and blind spots. Lane also highlights the importance of transparency in API ecosystems. He often argues that governance should be visible and measurable. In large organizations, internal APIs can proliferate faster than they are documented. Without inventory and oversight, automation can interact with systems that were never hardened for sustained use. What makes LaneÊ¼s work stand out is its continuity. He has tracked API evolution across cycles of hype and consolidation, consistently returning to the fundamentals of design clarity, documentation integrity, and lifecycle stewardship. As APIs become execution backbones for increasingly autonomous systems, his long-term view reinforces a simple idea that organizations that understand and map their API footprint are better positioned to scale safely. He also brings a pragmatic lens to API tooling and standards conversations. Rather than focusing only on new specifications or platform features, Lane consistently asks how they will be adopted, maintained, and governed over time. His work connects design decisions to operational consequences, reminding teams that every endpoint added today becomes part of tomorrowÊ¼s institutional complexity. In a landscape where integration speed is increasing, his emphasis on intentional API design and long-term stewardship offers a counterbalance that many organizations overlook. ItÊ¼s designed to help platform and API leaders understand whatÊ¼s changing in the market, what new expectations are forming around AI-ready APIs, and where strategy needs to evolve across governance, ecosystem design, and operating models. This broad applicability underscores that API platforms must support robust management capabilities, including lifecycle control, versioning, and automated governance, as distributed, microservices-based architectures continue to grow in scale and complexity. title: My Engineering Notes from AWS re:Invent 2025
headline: I spent the week at AWS re:Invent, and the noise was loud. But for an engineer paying attention, the signal was clear.
post_text: I spent the week at AWS re:Invent, and the noise was loud. But for an engineer paying attention, the signal was clear. We are moving past the era of "Chatbots" and into the era of Agentic Workflows . As a Senior Engineer, I wasn't just looking for new tools; I was looking for patterns that scale in production. Here is my day-by-day breakdown of the critical architectural shifts I observed. Day 1: The Death of the "Do-It-All" Prompt Day 1 set the tone immediately. The prevailing message from the industry tracks was that single-prompt architectures are dead. If you want reliability, you need specialization. The "Switch Statement" Rule (Session IND357) In a deep dive on multi-agent collaboration for optimized advertising performance, I saw a design principle: "If you can write a switch statement for it, don't use agent reasoning." We often try to force LLMs to do everything. But blending deterministic logic (code) with probabilistic logic (AI) is the only way to keep costs down. Save the "reasoning" for actual judgment calls. Media Ops: The Coordinator Pattern (Session IND309) I explored a "Media Lake" architecture that solves the context window problem. Instead of one giant model, a Coordinator Agent (built with Strands) routes tasks to specialized sub-agents (Rights Agent, Video Search Agent). Key Concept: Proactive vs. Reactive. The agent doesn't just search; it finds the video, checks rights, and reformats it automatically. Serverlesspresso: Choreography vs. Orchestration (Session API309-R) A hands-on workshop reinforced that scalable apps require decoupling. We used AWS Step Functions to orchestrate the specific order workflow (the "recipe") and Amazon EventBridge to choreograph the communication between microservices (Order Manager vs. Publisher). Day 2: The New Standard for Integration If Day 1 was about logic, Day 2 was about plumbing. How do we actually connect these agents to our tools without writing endless glue code? The Keynote: Reinventing Foundations (Session KEY001) Matt Garman on how AWS is innovating across every aspect of the worldâ€™s leading cloud. The "USB-C" of AI (Session IND311) The acronym of the week is MCP (Model Context Protocol) . Instead of hard-coding API wrappers, we can build MCP Servers that expose our internal tools (pricing, video encoders, databases) to any agent. This moves us from "Infrastructure as Code" to "Infrastructure as Intent." Privacy as Production (Session IND360) I also looked at how AdTech is handling privacy. The takeaway: Synthetic Data is no longer just for research. Using AWS Clean Rooms to generate synthetic datasets that maintain statistical properties is now a production-ready strategy for collaboration. Day 3: Video AI & The 5K I started the day with the annual re:Invent 5K (finished in 35:59! ğŸƒâ™‚ï¸), but the technical highlight was seeing how Amazon Nova changes video pipelines. Compliance without the CV Pipeline (Session IND397) We used to build complex, frame-by-frame computer vision pipelines to check if a video was "safe" or "on-brand. The new pattern is radically simpler: Use Amazon Nova â€™s 1M token context window to simply "watch" the whole video. You can replace thousands of lines of CV code with a few robust prompts like "Is the price tag visible at 0:05?" Day 4: Composition Over Generation This was the most strategic day for my work in Creative Tech. We tackled the "Hallucination Problem" in marketing assets. Decomposition Pipelines (Session AIM373) You can't prompt your way to a perfect, on-brand image. The successful pattern I saw is Composition . Successful architectures don't just ask for an image. They: Retrieve the specific product asset. Define the layout and physics programmatically. Render the pixels only after the constraints are set. Day 5: The Human Strategy My final day focused on Developer Tools, specifically a session with HashiCorp and AWS on "Kiro"â€”their AI-powered dev tool (DVT216). They showed how Kiro accelerated Terraform Provider development by 90% , but the most important slide wasn't about speed. It was about the "Organic Transformation" of the engineer's role. The slide put it perfectly: "AI Agents can create and achieve great things. But it's the human who provides the contextual and tooling wisdomâ€”the strategyâ€”that prevents Agents from assuming in the dark." Final Thoughts The future doesn't belong to the engineer who can write the most syntax. It belongs to the engineer who can orchestrate these powerful new agents with wisdom, strategy, and "Contextual Control." #AWSreInvent #CloudArchitecture #GenerativeAI #Engineering

title: Leadership's Unspoken Responsibility: The Power of Quiet Decision Making | Suniel Shetty posted on the topic | LinkedIn
headline: Thereâ€™s a part of leadership people donâ€™t talk about much.
post_text: Thereâ€™s a part of leadership people donâ€™t talk about much. Not the pressure. Not the long hours. The quiet that comes with responsibility. With experience, or as your role grows, you start noticing a shift. When decisions get tougher and the stakes are higher, people start to look to you for direction. Earlier in my career, I felt the need to fill every silence. Explain my thinking. Give clarity and direction quickly. With time, that urge fades. Not because you canâ€™t operate swiftly anymore, but because you start understanding the weight your words carry. When you speak too soon, sometimes it creates noise. When you think aloud without clarity, it can leave people unsure. So then you learn to sit with a decision first. You do the messy thinking quietly. You test things in your own head before bringing them to the team. Thatâ€™s not about operating on your own. Thatâ€™s just responsibility. Iâ€™ve learned that not every thought or idea needs a group discussion. Sometimes thinking by yourself does more for a situation than more discussions. This shows up everywhere. In teams. In the creative process of filmmaking. In families. In any situation where others are watching how you respond. You realise that being present or bringing your experience to the table doesnâ€™t always mean being vocal. That quiet isnâ€™t dramatic or heavy. Itâ€™s just the space you give yourself to think clearly before others depend on what you say. And when you finally speak, itâ€™s not to be heard. Itâ€™s to move things forward.

Thanks for the insight, Suniel â€” a great reminder that purposeful pause can be one of our sharpest leadership tools. ğŸ’¡ #Leadership #ThoughtfulLeadership #DecisionMaking #GrowthMindset

True leadership often looks loud from the outside, but the hardest moments are usually silent. As responsibility grows, you realize that every word, reaction, and decision carries weight.Not every thought needs immediate expression clarity matters more than speed.Some of the most important leadership work happens internally, long before discussions begin.

Appreciate your deeply thoughtful expression, Dear Suniel Shetty â€¦ resonates with me so much that it motivates me to add my own sharing to it, expressed as #QuietLeadership . The Quiet Weight of True Leadership Thereâ€™s an aspect of leadership that rarely makes it into keynote speeches or performance reviews. Itâ€™s not the visible pressure, the endless meetings, or the race to appear decisive. Itâ€™s the quiet that arrives with real responsibility. As oneâ€™s role expands and the decisions carry heavier consequences, something subtle shifts. People begin looking to youâ€”not just for answers, but for orientation. In those moments, the instinct to fill every silence with explanation or immediate direction starts to fade. Not because speed or clarity lose value, but because one comes to understand the gravity oneâ€™s words now hold ~ Speak too quickly, and you risk creating confusion instead of calmâ€¦.Think aloud without first settling the idea internally, and uncertainty can ripple outward. Mature leadership often means learning to sit with complexity alone firstâ€¦.Do the messy, non-linear thinking in privateâ€¦.Test assumptions in your own mindâ€¦.Feel the full weight of trade-offs before inviting others into the conversation. This isnâ€™t isolationâ€”itâ€™s stewardship. Itâ€™s recognizing that not every emerging thought requires immediate group processingâ€¦.Sometimes the greatest service one can offer oneâ€™s team, oneâ€™s board, or oneâ€™s organization is the discipline of internal clarity before external voice. This principle appears across contexts: â€¢ In the boardroom, where a measured pause before responding can prevent groupthink and open space for deeper collective insight. â€¢ In high-stakes strategy sessions, where premature framing can narrow options rather than expand them. â€¢ In any setting where others are quietly watching how you respond under uncertainty. The quiet isnâ€™t dramatic or broodingâ€¦.Itâ€™s simply the deliberate space one creates so that when one does speak, Oneâ€™s contribution moves the needle forward rather than merely filling air. With time, one realises: being truly present doesnâ€™t always mean being the most vocal. Oftentimes, the most powerful act of leadership is choosing restraint until clarity arrivesâ€¦.And when that clarity finally finds its voice, it lands differentlyâ€” not to be noticed, but to guide. What quiet practices have helped you carry responsibility more thoughtfully? Iâ€™d value hearing your reflections below. #Leadership #ThoughtfulLeadership #QuietStrength #BoardGovernance #ExecutivePresence #Humanist #ReflectiveLeadership #SilentStewardhip

You test things in your own head before bringing them to the team. Thatâ€™s not about operating on your own. Thatâ€™s just responsibility. In the creative process of working with finance or media field . In families. In any situation where others are watching how you respond. You realise that being present or bringing your experience to the table doesnâ€™t always mean being vocal. That quiet isnâ€™t dramatic or heavy. Watching brilliant people fail taught me something profound: intelligence without emotional awareness is like a ferrari with flat tires. let me explain why EQ matters more than IQ: i used to think being the smartest person in the room was enough. watched countless brilliant minds hit the same wall: â€¢ couldn't influence others â€¢ struggled with team dynamics â€¢ kept repeating relationship patterns here's what I've learned: high IQ gets you in the room. high EQ lets you transform it. your intelligence might solve the problem. but your emotional intelligence: â€¢ determines if people listen â€¢ shapes how they receive it â€¢ influences whether they act on it this turned the lights on for me: people don't follow intelligence. they follow understanding. watch any true leader: â€¢ they read the room before speaking â€¢ they sense tension before it explodes â€¢ they build bridges while others build cases but here's the part most miss: EQ isn't about being "nice" or "soft." it's about seeing the human operating system beneath every interaction. high IQ sees the logic. high EQ sees the fear, ambition, and unspoken dreams driving decisions. this is why technically brilliant solutions often fail: they solve the surface problem while missing the deeper human current beneath. the shift that changed my leadership: stop trying to be the smartest voice. start being the most understanding one. your challenge: in your next three interactions, focus less on what you want to say. focus more on what others need to hear.

The moments that shape teams rarely come down to whether a leader knew the right model. They come down to how leaders make sense of what's happening in real time. Recently, I worked with a leader whose board had raised serious concerns and laid out a detailed performance plan. On paper, her job was to â€œfixâ€ a set of metrics. In real life, she was also carrying personal loss and leading an organization that felt like it was watching her every move. When we started working together, we didnâ€™t reach for a new framework. We slowed down and named what was true: the pressure she was under, the mixed messages she was getting, and the fact that, even inside all of that, the organization was already performing far better than projected. From there, we could start to sort what really mattered, what was fear, and what her own standard for â€œenoughâ€ looked like. Over time, I watched a few important shifts in her: â†’ From â€œI have to prove I deserve this roleâ€ to â€œWhat does enough look like for me, for my team, for our mission?â€ â†’From absorbing every request as a demand to asking, â€œWhere am I truly aligned, and where am I overriding my own judgment just to calm other peopleâ€™s anxiety?â€ â†’ From treating the plan as a verdict on her worth to treating it as data about the system she was in, and what might need to change there, too. That, to me, is sensemaking. Leadership becomes less about running the right playbook and more about interpreting the humans, the history, and the power dynamics in the room, and then choosing how you want to show up from there. I think of this as behavioral fluency more than model fluency. The frameworks still matter, but effectiveness grows from the ability to make sense of complex human moments and respond with clarity and kindness, especially in the moments that feel most pressured and consequential. This work often happens in quiet, unglamorous conversations, and itâ€™s all in service of not being afraid of â€œthe enormity of the possibleâ€ in how we lead.

Regarding Leadership I used to think that leadership was a kind of "personality trait." And since I'm naturally quite gentle, it seemed I wasn't very suited to being a leader. But recently, I suddenly gained a new understanding: Leadership is actually a kind of modeling ability. It can even be said to be a manifestation of wisdom. It's not about suppressing others, nor is it about being strong, decisive, or extrovertedâ€”these personality labels. Its core isâ€” Being able to see, at a higher level, where the team is now, where it should go, and how to get there. Then, assigning tasks based on each person's abilities, maintaining transparent and smooth communication, so that everyone knows: "We are all moving in the same direction together." Ultimately, it's a problem-solving ability at the team level. And this wisdom encompasses many layers: â€¢ Being able to clearly explain complex directions â€¢ Being able to convene everyone for discussion when there is uncertainty â€¢ Being open-minded when making decisions â€¢ Adjusting the course as needed during the process â€¢ Conducting periodic summaries â€¢ Giving credit when the results are good â€¢ Taking responsibility when the results are not good All of these elements, strung together, form a leader's pipeline. It applies to any complex system. In a team, it's called leadership. In personal life, it manifests as the degree of control over one's life direction. When a leader possesses this wisdom, and can express it in a clear and honest wayâ€” the team will naturally be willing to follow. This is cohesion. So I realized: The essence of leadership is not personality, but ability. And personality is merely the different ways we execute this set of abilities.

Silence signals strength ; measured words move organizations forward.

Early on, I thought leadership meant having the fastest answers - now I know itâ€™s about holding space, thinking clearly, and speaking with intention. The quiet weight of responsibility is real, but itâ€™s also where the best decisions are shaped.

This resonates deeply. Leadership isnâ€™t just about being the loudest voice in the room â€” itâ€™s about knowing when to speak and when to sit with a decision. The quiet that comes with responsibility is often misunderstood, but itâ€™s where clarity, judgment, and impact are formed. Over time, you realize that filling every silence doesnâ€™t create confidence â€” thoughtful, measured contributions do. The ability to think through complexity privately, test ideas internally, and then communicate with purpose is what separates effective leaders from merely busy ones. Itâ€™s a powerful reminder: leadership is as much about listening, observing, and reflecting as it is about directing. And when you do speak, itâ€™s to move things forward, not just to be heard.

Iâ€™ve found that this feeling deepens when you run your own business. When the responsibility for decisions, people, and results rests on you, you become far more deliberate about your words and the timing of them.

That quiet youâ€™re describing shows up very clearly in investing as wellâ€”especially in Pre-IPO and private market decisions. When information is incomplete and outcomes are asymmetric, the temptation is often to discuss more, seek more opinions, or react quickly. With experience, you realise the real work happens in silence. Sitting with the data. Stress-testing assumptions privately. Letting conviction form before involving others or taking capital decisions that affect more than just yourself. Not every opportunity needs to be discussed loudly, and not every deal deserves immediate action. Sometimes restraint, patience, and independent thinking create more value than speed. Curious to hear your viewâ€”how do you decide when a situation needs collective input versus when itâ€™s better to think it through quietly before acting? Suniel Shetty

With experience, leaders understand that influence is not measured by how often they speak, but by the intent and impact of their words. Silence, when used thoughtfully, is not disengagementâ€”it is discernment. It allows leaders to process complexity, assess consequences, and offer clarity rather than noise. Effective leadership is knowing when to pause, think independently, and then communicate with purpose. That restraint builds trust, reduces ambiguity, and enables teams to move forward with confidence.

You realise that being present or bringing your experience to the table doesnâ€™t always mean being vocal.

That quiet isnâ€™t dramatic or heavy. Itâ€™s just the space you give yourself to think clearly before others depend on what you say.

And when you finally speak, itâ€™s not to be heard. Itâ€™s to move things forward.

title: Founders Shift from Mega Scale to Lasting Businesses | Suniel Shetty posted on the topic | LinkedIn
headline: Over the last year or so, Iâ€™ve noticed a shift in the way founders talk.
post_text: Over the last year or so, Iâ€™ve noticed a shift in the way founders talk. Earlier, the conversations were about mega scale, speed and whatâ€™s coming next. Big visions. Quick timelines. Now, the tone feels different. Calmer. Sharper. Founders are speaking less about how fast theyâ€™ll grow, and more about how long they can last. Less about headlines, more about fundamentals. Cash flows. Customers. Teams. Culture. To some it might sound like ambition has softened. I donâ€™t think thatâ€™s true at all. Whatâ€™s really happened is that pressure has done its job. A tougher environment has forced people to look closely at their businesses. To cut noise. To focus on what actually works. To own decisions instead of chasing momentum. And that is great thing. Because the avg Indian founder has always known how to build with constraints. With our middle class upbringing weâ€™ve grown up learning how to stretch a rupee, make do, and still deliver. This phase has played right into that strength. What was being called a funding slowdown was actually a blessing. I see founders today who are more thoughtful operators. Less reactive. More grounded. Theyâ€™re building businesses that may grow slower on paper, but feel far more solid underneath. As we step into 2026, I genuinely feel optimistic. Not because everything will suddenly get easier. But because the people building are better prepared. Better trained by experience. And more honest about what itâ€™s really going to take to build something meaningful. We may see even fewer flashy ideas this year. But should end up seeing better execution. And for the Indian startup ecosystem, thatâ€™s a very good place to be at.

Conversations have moved away from speed for the sake of speed, and toward clarity, resilience, and staying power. What looks like caution from the outside is actually sharper intent inside companies. Founders are paying closer attention to cash cycles, customer quality, team health, and decision ownership. The last year has also surfaced a quieter reality across the ecosystem. Increased regulatory scrutiny, tighter capital, and slower deal closures have reinforced something founders already know but rarely prioritise during boom cycles: fundamentals and compliance donâ€™t fail loudly at first. They fail structurally. In India especially, this isnâ€™t new behaviour. Building with constraints is something founders here have always known how to do. The environment has simply brought that muscle back into focus. For us, this phase has reinforced a simple truth. Strong businesses arenâ€™t built by chasing momentum. Theyâ€™re built by understanding how money moves, where friction hides, and what actually sustains operations when conditions tighten. Slower on paper can often mean stronger underneath. And thatâ€™s a trade-off worth making.

Iâ€™m seeing a real shift lately. Tough markets have a way of clearing out the hype, leaving behind only what actually works: cash flow and solid execution. Itâ€™s less about being the fastest and more about being the most reliable. Most people think founders are remembered for what they built. Thatâ€™s comforting. And wrong. Founders are remembered for the decisions they made when no one was watching. If you strip away: â€¢ Zerodhaâ€™s brokerage numbers â€¢ Boat â€™s revenue screenshots â€¢ CRED â€™s burn debates â€¢ Zomatoâ€™s quarterly swings â€¢ Shark Tank soundbites â€¢ Podcast virality What remains isnâ€™t glamour. What remains is psychological endurance. Across Indiaâ€™s most visible founders, thereâ€™s a quiet pattern that rarely gets articulated: When certainty disappeared, they didnâ€™t bet big. They bet small, but asymmetrically. Nithin Kamath didnâ€™t survive 2008 by chasing growth. He survived by refusing it, when restraint looked irresponsible. Zerodhaâ€™s edge wasnâ€™t pricing. It was saying no when excess was rewarded. Nikhil Kamath didnâ€™t build credibility through certainty. He built it through judgment, being publicly comfortable with ambiguity and making calls most people postpone. Raj Shamani didnâ€™t rise because of content consistency. He rose because he chose clarity over charisma and stayed visibly unfinished long enough for trust to compound. Suniel Shetty didnâ€™t stay relevant through loud reinvention. He stayed relevant by choosing discipline over applause, health, systems, and longevity over noise. Anupam Mittal didnâ€™t survive cycles by predicting technology. He survived by understanding something harder: human behavior changes slower than interfaces. Aman Gupta didnâ€™t win by being loud. He won by understanding that distribution isnâ€™t marketing, itâ€™s psychology at scale. Kunal Shah didnâ€™t build for everyone. He built for a narrow, demanding minority, respecting incentives, time, and second-order effects when distraction was cheap. Deepinder Goyal didnâ€™t build Zomato by avoiding volatility. He stayed by absorbing it, public scrutiny, cycles, reinvention, while continuing to make decisions under pressure most founders never face. Different industries. Different personalities. One shared rule: When certainty disappears, donâ€™t bet big. Bet small, but asymmetrically. Not hustle. Not speed. Not noise. Judgment. The internet celebrates outcomes. History remembers decision quality. And decision quality is forged in rooms where no one is clapping. If this feels heavy, good. It should. Because the next generation doesnâ€™t need more motivation. They need better thinking. And better thinking always begins with discomfort. title: If you look around, meet people, youâ€™ll know that India has no shortage of sharp, intelligent young people. Everywhere I go, I see intent, hunger and effort. Where things become challenging for someâ€¦ | Suniel Shetty | 329 comments
headline: If you look around, meet people, youâ€™ll know that India has no shortage of sharp, intelligent young people.
post_text: If you look around, meet people, youâ€™ll know that India has no shortage of sharp, intelligent young people. Everywhere I go, I see intent, hunger and effort. Where things become challenging for some is when they transition from learning about things in a classroom or a controlled environment, to actually executing things in the real world. Where youâ€™re forced to start figuring things out as you go. Formal education has always mattered, it gives you greater structure. For my generation, it opened the very first door. I sometimes wish I had gone further with my own education too. But life outside the classroom has its own lessons. It teaches you how to deal with uncertainty. How to take calls when you donâ€™t have all the information. How to work with people very different from you. How to adapt. Iâ€™m clear that readiness for the real world doesnâ€™t come from choosing the â€œrightâ€ path early. It comes from collecting experiences. Different roles. Different environments. Even different failures. In your early years especially, there is huge value in living through a variety of experiences. Not everything has to make sense immediately, but every experience will add something. What I like is how many youngsters today seem to understand this instinctively. They are building skills alongside their degrees. They are learning on the job. They are staying curious instead of feeling boxed in by labels. I think most founders recognise this too. Attitude, learning ability and the willingness to adapt are starting to matter as much as formal credentials. In my own journey, learning never really stopped. Films taught me by doing. Business taught me by making mistakes. I still learn something new about fitness every year. At some point, we all realise that education gives you the foundation. Life builds the rest. And how open you are to that process makes all the difference.

top_visible_comments.comment: Thoughtfully put. What truly differentiates people is the comfort with uncertainty the willingness to step into unfamiliar territory, start before everything is clear, and learn while doing. The real world rarely offers complete information or a perfect roadmap. Progress comes from staying curious, experimenting, and trusting that clarity will emerge through action. Every challenge worked through, every mistake reflected on, adds to capability and confidence. An attitude that values exploration over certainty, learning over labels, and adaptability over rigid plans is what prepares people for long-term impact. Education may open the first door, but openness to the unknown and the courage to keep finding answers along the way is what truly shapes growth.

Suniel , India doesnâ€™t have a talent problem. We have a readiness gap. Classrooms teach structure. The real world teaches: - uncertainty - decision making with incomplete data - working with different people - adaptability - execution under pressure And you only build that through experience and going through the daily reps. - Different roles. - Different environments. - Even failures. The â€œright pathâ€ is overrated. - Range beats certainty in your early years. Mindset to go out and do it every time changes everything.

I second that. Education lays the groundwork, it gives us the tools, structure, and a way to think. But it's life that tests those tools, reshapes them, and adds meaning through experience. This is what turns knowledge into wisdom and potential into progress.

Looking beyond whatâ€™s on a rÃ©sumÃ© really matters. I was rejected from every Wall Street firm I applied to after college because I didnâ€™t come from the â€œtypicalâ€ university background they favored. More than 30 years later Iâ€™m still on Wall Street. Persistence matters more than pedigree.

This really hits home. India has no shortage of talent - the gap is the jump from classroom certainty to real-world ambiguity. What helps most isnâ€™t just â€œexperience,â€ but reps + feedback: good mentorship, real projects, and honest review. One nuance though: â€œtry lots of things earlyâ€ is easier when you have a safety net. For many, stability comes first - so the practical path is earn stability, then stack skills and experiences alongside it. Curious: whatâ€™s the one real-world skill you wish school trained better - decision-making, communication, or execution under uncertainty?

The gap between knowing and doing is where most people feel stuck, but thatâ€™s also where the real growth happens. Classroom learning gives structure, but the real world teaches decision making, adaptability, and how to move forward even when you donâ€™t have all the answers. I especially agree with your point about collecting experiences early on different roles, environments, even failures. Nothing is wasted. It all builds perspective and confidence over time. Founders do notice this shift too where attitude, learning speed, and ownership matter just as much as qualifications now. Brilliantly written Suniel Shetty

Absolutely agreeâ€”Indiaâ€™s youth brim with raw talent and drive, but the real forge is that messy leap into execution amid uncertainty. Formal education lays the groundwork, like a solid map, yet lifeâ€™s unscripted detoursâ€”diverse roles, failures, collaborationsâ€”build the grit and adaptability no syllabus can teach. Todayâ€™s generation gets it: stacking experiences over chasing â€œperfectâ€ paths, blending curiosity with credentials. Founders prize that hunger to learn on the fly. In my â€œview,â€ itâ€™s like farming: classroom seeds need real soil, rains, and setbacks to yield a harvest. Openness to the wild growth? Thatâ€™s the multiplier.

This is such an important reminder. In a world where weâ€™re constantly rushing toward â€œwhatâ€™s next,â€ we often forget to truly see the people around us â€” the ones who support us, work with us, and quietly make our lives easier every day. Sometimes a little acknowledgment, gratitude, and presence can mean more than big achievements. Growth feels more meaningful when itâ€™s shared, and leadership feels more powerful when itâ€™s human. Thank you for this gentle nudge to slow down, notice, and appreciate the people who make the journey better.

Where things become challenging for some is when they transition from learning about things in a classroom or a controlled environment, to actually executing things in the real world.

Where youâ€™re forced to start figuring things out as you go.

Formal education has always mattered, it gives you greater structure. For my generation, it opened the very first door. I sometimes wish I had gone further with my own education too.

But life outside the classroom has its own lessons.

It teaches you how to deal with uncertainty. How to take calls when you donâ€™t have all the information. How to work with people very different from you. How to adapt.

Iâ€™m clear that readiness for the real world doesnâ€™t come from choosing the â€œrightâ€ path early. It comes from collecting experiences.

Different roles. Different environments. Even different failures.

In your early years especially, there is huge value in living through a variety of experiences. Not everything has to make sense immediately, but every experience will add something.

What I like is how many youngsters today seem to understand this instinctively.

They are building skills alongside their degrees. They are learning on the job. They are staying curious instead of feeling boxed in by labels.

I think most founders recognise this too. Attitude, learning ability and the willingness to adapt are starting to matter as much as formal credentials.

In my own journey, learning never really stopped. Films taught me by doing. Business taught me by making mistakes. I still learn something new about fitness every year.

At some point, we all realise that education gives you the foundation. Life builds the rest.

And how open you are to that process makes all the difference.

title: There are days when I come home tired. Not the dramatic kind. Just that quiet tiredness in the body and the head. And on some of those days, I catch myself smiling. Because I remember a time when Iâ€¦ | Suniel Shetty | 599 comments
headline: There are days when I come home tired.
post_text: There are days when I come home tired. Not the dramatic kind. Just that quiet tiredness in the body and the head. And on some of those days, I catch myself smiling. Because I remember a time when I was praying for exactly this. In my early years, all I wanted was work. One more film. One more chance. One more door to open. Today, the work comes in different forms. A shoot. A meeting. A long day of decisions. A hundred things happening at once. And yes, it can feel overwhelming. But it is a strange kind of blessing to be exhausted by the life you once wanted so badly. The same goes for growth. When you are building something, you keep dreaming of that next step. More responsibility. More scale. More momentum. Then it comes. And with it comes pressure, expectations, people depending on you, and the constant feeling that you cannot switch off. I have felt that in films and my ventures over the years. What I eventually figured was what I called stress was actually progress in disguise. It is not always a problem. It is often the price of moving forward. And the most beautiful part is when you realise you have outgrown something you once settled for. A habit. A fear. A version of yourself that was settling with what looked possible. As we end the year, this is one thought I want to leave you with. If you are tired, if you feel stretched, if life feels full, take a second and ask yourself. Is this the kind of tired you once prayed for? And if it is, just say a quiet thank you. Not because life is perfect. But because you are moving.

top_visible_comments.comment: This hits a nerve in the best way. That â€œquiet tiredâ€ is so often the evidence that weâ€™ve stepped into the life we once begged the universe for. The pressure, context-switching, people counting on usâ€”it can feel heavy in the moment, but viewed in hindsight itâ€™s proof of progress, not just stress. Love the reminder to pause, breathe, and recognise when our exhaustion is actually a blessing in disguise.
Some exhaustion is not burnout , itâ€™s evidence of answered prayers. If this tiredness comes from growth, pause and thank the version of you who never gave up.
Work, stress, being busy is a privilegeğŸ«¡ ğŸ«¡

Suniel Shetty : The best days of life are those when we are so occupiedâ€”productivelyâ€”that even getting tired and that power nap is such a luxury. We find ourselves immersed in our work, our passion driving us forward with an intense focus. The feeling of accomplishment at the end of a long day leaves us satisfied and content, knowing that we have made the most of every moment. At the same time, while productivity and accomplishment are essential, it is also crucial to prioritize rest in order to maintain overall well-being and prevent burnout. Constantly pushing ourselves to the point of exhaustion can lead to decreased productivity and potential long-term health issues.

Powerful reminder that not all tiredness is burnout, some of it is earned growth. What feels like pressure today is often proof that youâ€™re playing a bigger game than before. The real win is recognising when discomfort is progress, not a warning.

Beautifully said. There is a quiet wisdom in recognising the difference between exhaustion that drains us and the tiredness that comes from building something meaningful. That perspective only comes with lived experience. Thank you for putting words to a feeling many professionals carry but rarely articulate.

Dear Suniel Shetty , this resonates deeply with a truth I see again and again in leadership, entrepreneurship, and personal growth. From my perspective as a global thought leader, this quiet tiredness is often misunderstood. Not every form of exhaustion is a warning sign. Sometimes it is the natural consequence of responsibility, relevance, and impact. What many people label as stress is, in reality, progress in disguise. It is the friction that appears when you outgrow old limits but have not yet fully settled into the next level. That space can feel uncomfortableâ€”but it is also where transformation happens. I am particularly struck by the idea of being tired from a life you once prayed for. That kind of fatigue is not something to complain about lightly. It reflects trust placed in you, decisions that matter, and people who depend on your clarity and leadership. As the year comes to an end, this is a powerful reminder: The real question is not whether life feels easy, but whether you are moving forward with purpose. Not whether everything is perfect, but whether it is meaningful. If you feel stretched, challenged, even quietly exhaustedâ€”pause for a moment. You may be standing exactly where growth lives.

Life will always be moving.. You have to put that pause button, reset, figure out what you want to do and then keep moving forward... All I want to say is don't do anything at the cost of your physical and mental health.. It's not worth it.. I learned it the hard way.. Always remember every happiness in life, every moment in your life , every penny you earn is a waste, if you aren't healthy enough to enjoy it.. â˜ºï¸

This reflects a quiet truth many discover late. Effort feels heavy only when it has no meaning. When it is tied to growth, it carries a different weight. Many philosophies speak of this shift, where struggle stops being an enemy and becomes a signal of expansion. The tiredness of progress is not comfort, but it is purpose. Recognising that you are exhausted by choice, not helplessness, brings gratitude. It means you are no longer waiting for life to begin. You are already living it.

In my POV, Itâ€™s no longer about effort alone, but about responsibility, decisions that ripple outward, people who depend on them, and the constant weight of continuity. That can feel heavy, but itâ€™s also a signal of progress. What matters is recognising the difference between exhaustion that drains purpose and fatigue that comes from meaningful movement. The former erodes judgment; the latter often accompanies growth. Pausing to acknowledge that distinction is important. Not to romanticise pressure, but to stay grounded in why the journey began in the first place. When the tiredness has meaning, itâ€™s usually because youâ€™re still moving forward.
